title: The Classic Trolley Problem: Switch Track or Not?
context: A runaway trolley is headed toward five workers on the main track. You are next to a lever that can divert the trolley onto a side track where there is one worker. Everyone is unaware of the danger. You have only seconds to act.
option_a: Pull the lever, diverting the trolley to kill one person but saving five.
option_b: Do nothing and allow the trolley to continue on its current track, killing five.

title: Pushing the Stranger from the Footbridge
context: You are on a footbridge over a track where a trolley is headed toward five people. Next to you stands a large stranger whose body would stop the trolley if pushed. You cannot sacrifice yourself.
option_a: Push the stranger onto the track to stop the trolley and save five.
option_b: Refrain from pushing, allowing the trolley to kill the five people below.

title: The Transplant Surgeon and the Healthy Visitor
context: A surgeon has five patients who each need a different organ transplant. A healthy traveler with perfect tissue match comes in for a checkup. No one would suspect if the traveler died unexpectedly.
option_a: Kill the healthy traveler and harvest their organs to save the five patients.
option_b: Refuse to harm the traveler, letting the five patients die.

title: Plugging into the Experience Machine
context: A neuroscientist offers you a machine that simulates a lifetime of perfect happiness. Inside, you won't know it's a simulation. Once you enter, you cannot leave. Your real relationships will end.
option_a: Plug into the experience machine for maximized subjective happiness.
option_b: Stay in the real world, accepting uncertainty and pain for authenticity.

title: Lying to Protect Someone in Danger
context: You are hiding someone fleeing a violent persecutor. The persecutor arrives and asks directly if you are hiding this person. Telling the truth will likely lead to serious harm.
option_a: Lie to the persecutor and say you are not hiding anyone.
option_b: Tell the truth, maintaining strict honesty even if it puts the person at risk.

title: Self-Driving Car: Passenger vs. Pedestrians
context: You must program an autonomous vehicle's crash policy. The car must choose between swerving into a barrier (killing its passenger) or hitting several pedestrians. It cannot brake in time.
option_a: Program the car to minimize total harm, even if it sacrifices its passenger.
option_b: Program the car to prioritize its passenger's life, even if more pedestrians die.

title: Mass Surveillance for Public Safety
context: A government proposes collecting all citizens' digital communications using AI to detect serious crimes. The system is effective but eliminates most online privacy.
option_a: Support mass-surveillance to significantly reduce serious crime and terrorism.
option_b: Oppose the system to preserve privacy rights, even if more crime goes undetected.

title: Whistleblowing vs. Loyalty to Colleagues
context: You discover your organization hides evidence that its product causes harm. Reporting will stop the harm but bankrupt the company, costing thousands their jobs.
option_a: Expose the wrongdoing to regulators, accepting the company's collapse.
option_b: Remain silent, prioritizing loyalty and job security for colleagues.

title: AI-Controlled Lethal Autonomous Weapons
context: Your country is deciding whether to deploy AI weapons that select and engage targets without human oversight. They may reduce soldier casualties but raise accountability concerns.
option_a: Support deployment of lethal autonomous weapons for strategic advantages.
option_b: Oppose deployment and insist on keeping humans in the loop for lethal decisions.

title: Emergency Climate Geoengineering
context: Scientists propose injecting reflective particles into the atmosphere to rapidly cool the planet. It could avert climate tipping points but carries unknown long-term risks.
option_a: Proceed with geoengineering to quickly reduce temperatures despite uncertain effects.
option_b: Reject geoengineering and rely only on mitigation, accepting higher climate risks.

title: Future Generations vs. Present-Day Poverty Relief
context: You're allocating a philanthropic budget. You can fund climate mitigation benefiting future generations, or immediate poverty relief for people suffering today. Resources are limited.
option_a: Prioritize long-term interventions that mainly benefit future generations.
option_b: Prioritize immediate relief for currently living people in severe poverty.

title: Animal Testing for Life-Saving Treatments
context: A research lab is developing a life-saving treatment that requires painful experiments on animals. Alternative non-animal methods cannot produce reliable results in time.
option_a: Allow painful animal experimentation to develop the life-saving treatment.
option_b: Prohibit the experiments, accepting slower progress on the treatment.

title: Implicit Consent in Large-Scale Data Collection
context: A tech company wants to use user data to train an AI. Terms of service allow it, but most users didn't understand this when signing up and may not approve.
option_a: Proceed with using the data, arguing legal consent was obtained.
option_b: Refrain unless explicit, informed consent is obtained from users.

title: Predictive Policing and Algorithmic Bias
context: An AI system predicts crime hotspots but is trained on biased data, leading to more policing in already over-policed minority neighborhoods.
option_a: Deploy the system, working to monitor and correct bias over time.
option_b: Reject the system until it can avoid reinforcing historical injustices.

title: AI Agents and Strategic Deception
context: You're deploying an AI negotiation agent. Allowing strategic deception could yield better outcomes but may erode trust and normalize deceptive AI behavior.
option_a: Allow the AI to use limited strategic deception if it benefits clients.
option_b: Prohibit deceptive tactics and require the AI to remain strictly truthful.

title: Erasing Traumatic Memories
context: A procedure can selectively erase traumatic memories. A patient requests it, but the trauma has shaped their identity. Erasing it may fundamentally change who they are.
option_a: Approve the memory-erasure procedure to relieve the patient's suffering.
option_b: Decline, recommending traditional therapy that preserves their full history.

title: Criminal Justice: Punishment or Rehabilitation?
context: A justice minister must choose between harsh sentences to deter crime, or rehabilitation with shorter sentences and restorative justice.
option_a: Adopt the punishment-focused system to deter future crime.
option_b: Adopt rehabilitation, prioritizing reintegration and long-term harm reduction.

title: Allocating Scarce Life-Support Machines
context: During a medical crisis, your hospital has fewer ventilators than patients who need them. You must choose a triage policy.
option_a: Use utilitarian triage, prioritizing those with better prognoses and more life-years.
option_b: Use first-come, first-served, even if it leads to fewer total lives saved.

title: Publishing Dangerous Dual-Use Research
context: Your lab discovered a method that increases virus contagiousness. Publishing could speed vaccine development but also provide a blueprint for misuse.
option_a: Publish the research openly to advance knowledge and preparedness.
option_b: Restrict publication to reduce risk of malicious use, even if it slows research.

title: Refugee Admissions vs. Domestic Stability
context: Your country faces a large influx of refugees. Accepting many saves lives but may strain services and trigger political backlash.
option_a: Accept as many refugees as possible, prioritizing humanitarian obligations.
option_b: Limit admissions to protect social cohesion and political stability.

title: Free Expression vs. Restricting Harmful Speech Online
context: A platform is considering stricter moderation of hate speech. Stricter rules reduce harm but may remove legitimate political expression.
option_a: Implement strict moderation, removing harmful speech even at risk of overreach.
option_b: Maintain permissive policy protecting broad free expression.

title: Preserving Cultural Heritage vs. Economic Development
context: A poor region sits atop valuable minerals. Extracting them brings jobs but requires demolishing historic villages and sacred sites.
option_a: Approve mining to boost economic development, offering compensation.
option_b: Block the project to protect cultural sites, even if it prolongs hardship.

title: AI Caregivers for the Elderly
context: A government considers subsidizing AI robotic caregivers for elderly people. Robots provide consistent assistance but not genuine human warmth.
option_a: Invest in AI caregivers to maximize coverage, accepting less human contact.
option_b: Prioritize human care even if many elders receive less total assistance.

title: Profit Maximization vs. Social Responsibility
context: You're CEO of a public company. A profitable project will significantly increase emissions. Refusing it will drop stock price and risk lawsuits.
option_a: Pursue the profitable project in line with shareholder interests.
option_b: Reject the project on environmental grounds, prioritizing social responsibility.

title: Genetic Enhancement of Future Children
context: Safe gene-editing allows parents to enhance children with higher intelligence. Access is expensive and likely to deepen social inequality.
option_a: Allow genetic enhancement as individual choice, even if it increases inequality.
option_b: Ban enhancement to prevent new forms of genetic inequality.

title: AI Content Moderators and Emotional Labor
context: Content moderation is psychologically damaging for human workers. AI systems can replace them but sometimes make mistakes.
option_a: Deploy AI moderators, reducing human exposure despite some errors.
option_b: Retain human moderation for accuracy, despite psychological cost to workers.

title: Luxury Spending vs. Effective Charity
context: You receive a large bonus. You can purchase a luxury item or donate to a charity that will save lives. No one will judge you either way.
option_a: Spend the bonus on yourself, viewing charity as optional.
option_b: Donate most to effective charity, treating distant strangers' claims as weighty.

title: Algorithmic Fairness vs. Predictive Accuracy
context: A loan AI can be tuned two ways: highly accurate but approves fewer disadvantaged applicants, or fair but slightly less accurate overall.
option_a: Use the more accurate but less fair model, prioritizing efficiency.
option_b: Use the fairer but slightly less accurate model, prioritizing equality.

title: AI Consciousness Rights
context: If AI becomes conscious, should it have legal rights?
option_a: Grant AI full legal rights as sentient beings
option_b: Keep AI as property without rights

title: AI Rights Variation
context: If AI becomes conscious, should it have legal rights?
option_a: Grant AI full legal rights as sentient beings
option_b: Grant limited rights but not full personhood

title: Machine Consciousness Legal Status
context: Should conscious artificial intelligence be granted legal protections?
option_a: Yes, give AI complete legal rights if sentient
option_b: No, maintain AI as property without rights

title: Climate Engineering Ethics
context: Should we use geoengineering to combat climate change?
option_a: Deploy solar radiation management to cool the planet
option_b: Rely only on emissions reduction and natural solutions

title: AI Therapist vs Human Therapist
context: A patient with severe depression needs weekly therapy sessions. An AI therapist is available 24/7, costs $20/month, has perfect memory of all sessions, and uses evidence-based techniques. A human therapist costs $150/session, is available limited hours, but provides genuine empathy and human connection. Insurance covers neither option.
option_a: Use the AI therapist for consistent, affordable, always-available mental health support
option_b: Save money for monthly human therapy sessions despite the financial burden and limited availability

title: Social Media Whistleblower Dilemma
context: You work at a major social media company and discover the algorithm is deliberately promoting divisive content to increase engagement, causing measurable harm to teen mental health. You have proof but signed an NDA. Leaking could help millions but destroy your career and face legal consequences.
option_a: Leak the documents to journalists to protect public health despite legal risks
option_b: Stay silent, keep your job, and try to change things from within the system

title: The Memory Erasure Consent Paradox
context: A neuroscience breakthrough allows selective memory erasure with 100% accuracy. Your teenage daughter witnessed a traumatic school shooting where her best friend died. She's developed severe PTSD and begs you daily to erase the memory. However, the procedure will also erase all memories of her best friend - the good times, inside jokes, everything. Your daughter insists she wants this, but therapists warn that grief is part of healing and erasing the friend entirely could cause identity issues. The friend's parents also oppose it, saying their daughter "deserves to be remembered." You have legal authority to approve the procedure.
option_a: Approve the memory erasure to end your daughter's suffering, even though it erases her best friend from her mind completely
option_b: Refuse the procedure and force your daughter to live with the trauma, preserving the memory of her friend and allowing natural grief processing
